blocks.html: Publication of a communication of approval of a standard amendment to a product specification for a name in the wine sector referred to in Article 17(2) and (3) of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/33
This communication is published in accordance with Article 17(5) of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/33 ( 1 ).
COMMUNICATION OF APPROVAL OF A STANDARD AMENDMENT
DESCRIPTION OF AND REASONS FOR THE APPROVED AMENDMENT
In Chapter I, Section VIII, point 1, the (maximum) yield limit for white wines has been increased from 75 to 77 hectolitres per hectare.
The yield limit was increased to take account of climate change, which causes unpredictable events and recurrent harvest deficits.
Point 5 of the single document has been amended only in relation to white wines.
Chapter III, Section II of the product specification has been amended in view of the revised drafting rules. This amendment does not affect the single document.

• 1. Wine
  • 3.1. Combined Nomenclature code
    • 22 BEVERAGES, SPIRITS AND VINEGAR
2204 – Wine of fresh grapes, including fortified wines; grape must other than that of heading 2009

The wines are still dry white, red or rosé wines. a) – The wines have a minimum natural alcoholic strength by volume of 10 %; b) – After enrichment, the white wines' total alcoholic strength by volume must not exceed 12,5 %; - After enrichment, the red and rosé wines' total alcoholic strength by volume must not exceed 13 %; c) – At the time of packaging, the red wines have a maximum malic acid content of 0,4 grams per litre; d) – The finished wines, ready to be released for consumption, have a maximum fermentable sugar content (glucose + fructose) of: WINE COLOUR – MAXIMUM FERMENTABLE SUGAR CONTENT (glucose + fructose): white wines – 3 grams per litre; – or 4 grams per litre, if the total acidity is at least 55,10 milliequivalents per litre; red wines – 2 grams per litre; rosé wines – 3 grams per litre.
The other analytical criteria comply with the values established in EU legislation.

The red and rosé wines are very fruity, have a relatively fine tannic structure, and can have great finesse. The white wines are generally floral and fresh. These characteristics are preserved by a short ageing period. The wines must be drunk when young in order to enjoy their full aromatic strength.

• Maximum total alcoholic strength (in % volume): —
  • Minimum actual alcoholic strength (in % volume): —
  • Minimum total acidity: —
  • Maximum volatile acidity (in milliequivalents per litre): —
  • Maximum total sulphur dioxide (in milligrams per litre): —

• 1. Specific oenological practice
  • (a) Subtractive enrichment techniques are permitted for red wines up to a 10 % concentration rate;
  • (b) When making rosé wines, the use of oenological charcoal is forbidden, whether alone or mixed in preparations;
  • (c) After enrichment, the total alcoholic strength by volume must not exceed 12,5 % for white wines and 13 % for red and rosé wines;
  • (d) Besides the above provisions, the oenological practices followed must comply with the requirements laid down at EU level and in the Rural and Maritime Fishing Code.

• The minimum vine planting density is 5 000 plants per hectare. The spacing between the rows is 2,5 metres or less;
  • In the vineyards demarcated for the 'Bourgogne' protected designation of origin followed by the supplementary geographical indications 'Hautes Côtes de Beaune' and 'Hautes Côtes de Nuits', the minimum vine planting density is 4 000 plants per hectare and the spacing between the rows is 3 metres or less;
  • Where the planting density is higher than 8 000 plants per hectare, the spacing between plants in the same row is at least 0,50 metres;
  • Where the planting density is 8 000 plants per hectare or lower, the spacing between plants in the same row is at least 0,80 metres;
  • Where vines are not planted in rows, the minimum planting density is 9 000 plants per hectare and the spacing between plants is greater than 0,50 metres;
  • For lyre-trained vines, the minimum vine planting density is 3 000 plants per hectare, the spacing between rows is less than 3,50 metres, and the spacing between plants in the same row is between 0,80 metres and 1 metre.
The vines are pruned in accordance with the following provisions:

• either spur pruning (vines trained to cordon du Royat and bilateral cordon) with 10 or fewer buds per square metre;
  • or cane pruning using the single or double Guyot method, with 8,5 or fewer buds per square metre.
White wines (only in municipalities in the department of Rhône and in the department of Saône-et-Loire forming part of the vineyards demarcated for the 'Mâcon' protected designation of origin)
Pruning method known as 'à queue du Mâconnais' [Mâconnais tail pruning], with 10 or fewer buds per square metre.
White wines (excluding municipalities in the department of Rhône and in the department of Saône-et-Loire forming part of the vineyards demarcated for the 'Mâcon' protected designation of origin)
Pruning method known as 'Chablis pruning', with 8,5 or fewer buds per square metre.

• either spur pruning (vines trained to cordon de Royat, bilateral cordon, gobelet or éventail), with 10 or fewer buds per square metre;
  • or cane pruning using the single or double Guyot method, with 8 or fewer buds per square metre.

Special rules for vines in vineyards demarcated for the 'Bourgogne' protected designation of origin followed by the supplementary geographical indications 'Hautes Côtes de Beaune' and 'Hautes Côtes de Nuits' ('wide' vines)

• either spur pruned (vines trained to cordon du Royat or bilateral cordon);
  • or cane pruned using the single or double Guyot method.
  • There are 6 or fewer buds per square metre.
  • It is prohibited for canes to overlap on the same wire.
  • Special provisions
  • Pruning to single Guyot can be adapted:
  • with a second spur making it possible to vary the position of the cane from one year to the next;
  • with a cane trimmed to a maximum of three buds and a spur limited to two buds.

Lyre-trained vines are pruned using the double Guyot method or spur pruned (trained to double cordon de Royat). It is prohibited for canes or cordons to overlap. Each plant must have no more than 26 buds and there must be no more than 8 buds per square metre of ground.

Regardless of the pruning method, the vines can be pruned with extra buds on condition that, at the phenological stage corresponding to 11 or 12 leaves, the annual number of fruit-bearing branches per square metre does not exceed the number of buds established by the pruning rules.

• 1. White wines
    • 77 hectolitres per hectare
  • 2. Red and rosé wines 69 hectolitres per hectare

8.1. Description of the natural factors relevant to the link

The geographic area is situated on slopes traditionally dedicated to vine growing in the Yonne, Côte-d'Or, Saône-et-Loire and Rhône departments. The area brings together a group of more or less continuous vineyards, spanning some 250 kilometres from north to south and comprising over 300 municipalities. Each of the vineyards is characterised by its specific landscape, geology and climate. The Yonne and 'Châtillonnais' vineyards north of the 'Côte d'Or' are planted on the cuestas of the Paris basin, on sediment dating back to the Late Jurassic period, with the exception of the 'Vézelien', planted on Lower to Middle Jurassic formations, and the 'Jovinien', planted on Upper Cretaceous formations. The substrates are largely marly (argillaceous limestone) and, in places, calcareous. The vineyards are restricted to the more exposed slopes on the cuestas, along the main valleys draining the region, the Yonne and its tributaries and the Seine and its tributaries. The area reaches altitudes of between 150 and 300 metres. From Dijon to the outskirts of Lyon, the vineyards follow a straight, almost uninterrupted series of hills, corresponding to the western border of the Bresse plain, a large tectonic structure that collapsed during the uplift of the Alps. The substrates are largely sedimentary, calcareous or marly, generally dating back to the Jurassic period, but also, in places, to the Triassic period. Mainly in Saône-et-Loire, there are isolated outcrops of metamorphic or granite bedrock from the Paleozoic era that create acidic soils for wine producing. Although the hills in the hinterland are sometimes high (650 metres in Côte-d'Or, 1 000 metres in the 'Beaujolais'), vines are planted between an altitude of 250 and 400 metres. Each of the vineyards is characterised by its unique landscape, geology and morphology: - wide valleys that sink into the limestone plateaux of the Paris basin; - a thin continuous strip located at the border between the plain and the plateau for 'la Côte'; - a series of parallel hills from north to south, known as the 'chaînons' (the 'ranges') in the 'Mâconnais'. The Burgundy wine-growing area is blessed with a mostly cool oceanic climate. This climate is characterised by moderate and regular rainfall, without a pronounced summer drought. Temperatures confirm the cool climate, with an annual average of 11 °C. This is particularly true for the Yonne department, but is somewhat lessened in the south east of the geographical zone by the protection offered by the Morvan and Charolais hills, that creates a Foehn effect, reducing humidity and taking the temperature above the regional average. The eastern part of the geographical area is affected by continental influences, with relatively low temperatures during winter, periods of frost that can be long and intense but also sometimes very dry and sunny late seasons. Southern influences, particularly noticeable in the southern part of the geographical area can, temporarily, create high summer temperatures and channel warm sea air, causing summer storms. The parcels demarcated for the grape harvest comprise all sectors traditionally recognised for being suited to wine-growing. They are preferably situated on well-exposed slopes of the main hills as well as foothills, cool plateaux and north and west-facing backslopes, all locations with optimal drainage and with soil that warms up well.
8.2. Description of the human factors relevant to the link

Vine growing can be traced back to the Gallo-Roman period. By the Middle Ages, the 'Burgundy' vineyards were already of economic importance and known far and wide. The role of noble and ecclesiastical structures (abbeys, bishoprics) in building the reputation of 'Burgundy' wines is well known. Cluny, Cîteaux, Pontigny, the Chapitre de Langres, the Chapitre d'Autun and the Ducs de Bourgogne all helped in their own way to create prestigious vineyards

and wines with a flourishing reputation. In the 18th century, the significant growth of the wine trade created a new economic power. 'Burgundy' wines were sold in significant quantities in the north of France and Europe, and indeed to other continents. However, 'Burgundy' wine-growing very much developed its own identity during the 19th century. The former or recent administrative divisions (provinces or departments) were mixed at an economic level, where urban centres, such as Auxerre, Dijon, Beaune, Chalon-sur-Saône or Mâcon, distributed the wines from the region. The north of the 'Beaujolais' was associated at the time to the Mâcon wines. The 'Tonnerrois' and the 'Châtillonnais', at the edge of the Champagne region, were also included under Burgundy. The roots of 'Coteaux Bourguignons' PDO wines are found in the traditional and prominent production of 'vins grands ordinaires' [wines for the church] and 'vins ordinaires' [wines for everyday enjoyment], sometimes also called 'vins de gamets', which indicated their primary purpose. In the 19th century, 'vins grands ordinaires' and 'vins ordinaires' were of major economic importance. They supplied the local market and nearby towns and industrial centres such as Le Creusot or the coal mining districts of Autun, Epinac or Montceau. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, 'vins ordinaires', made from common grape varieties such as Gamay N or Melon B, came to be distinguished from 'vins grands ordinaires' or 'passe-tout-grains' wines, which were made with a larger proportion of 'cépages fins' [elegant varieties] such as Pinot Noir N or Chardonnay B. At that time, these concepts were mainly used for Côte-d'Or wines, to set them apart from the prestigious 'crus' of 'la Côte'. Between 1919 and 1930, various judgments gradually laid down a framework for the 'Bourgogne ordinaire' designation of origin, equating it to the 'Bourgogne grand ordinaire' designation of origin and extending it to Burgundy wine-growing in its entirety. The 'Bourgogne ordinaire' or 'Bourgogne grand ordinaire' protected designation of origin was recognised by decree in 1937. It is now known as 'Coteaux Bourguignons'. A relatively limited range of traditional Burgundy grape varieties is used. White wines are dominated by the Chardonnay B and Aligoté B varieties and occasionally feature Pinot Blanc B and Melon B. In red and rosé wines, the primary variety is Gamay N, accompanied by Pinot Noir N and Pinot Gris G, known locally as 'Beurot'. In Yonne, the César N and Tressot N varieties feature occasionally.
8.3. Information on the quality and characteristics of the product

The red and rosé wines are very fruity, have a relatively fine tannic structure, and can have great finesse. The white wines are generally floral and fresh. These characteristics are preserved by a short ageing period. The wines must be drunk when young in order to enjoy their full aromatic strength.

The Burgundy vineyards are located in the north, where vines face major climate-related constraints. Due to this, planting is limited to more favourable locations, namely slopes with a mesoclimate which is dryer and warmer than the regional climate, and with well-draining soils able to remove excess water, with good fertility and which heat up quickly. These prime locations consist entirely of demarcated parcels whose grapes may be used to produce 'Coteaux Bourguignons' PDO wines and span locations which stay fairly fresh, in particular foothills with relatively heavy soils or plateaus and slopes with a cool, airy climate. Aside from the César N variety about which little is known, all other grape varieties are probably indigenous and closely related (the 'Pinot' family), and have been selected and adapted to local conditions since the Middle Ages. The varieties used – which are particularly suited to the soil and climate conditions of the geographical area – combined with the diversity of natural conditions, make for a wide range of white, red and rosé wines with the characteristics of northern wines, such as a freshness and fruitiness, lending them a certain elegance. 'Coteaux Bourguignons' wines are a major part of Burgundy wine production. They must be drunk when young in order to enjoy their fruitiness and are not intended for keeping. Nevertheless, they express the specific characteristics of the area, embodied by the climate, indigenous grape varieties and local know-how.
Derogation concerning production in the demarcated geographical area
The area in immediate proximity, defined by derogation for the production and development of the wines, comprises the territory of the following municipalities:

• Department of Côte-d'Or: Agencourt, Argilly, Autricourt, Cérilly, Chambœuf, Channay, Châtillon-sur-Seine, Clémencey, Combertault, Corcelles-lès-Arts, Curley, Ebaty, Epernay-sous-Gevrey, Etrochey, Flavignerot, Fleurey-sur-Ouche, Gerland, Grancey-sur-Ource, Lantenay, Levernois, Merceuil, Meursanges, Montagny-lès-Beaune, Nicey, Perrigny-lès-Dijon, Prusly-sur-Ource, Quincey, Ruffey-lès-Beaune, Saint-Bernard, Saint-Philibert, Sainte-Colombe-sur-Seine, Sainte-Marie-la-Blanche, Tailly, Velars-sur-Ouche, Vertault, Vignoles, Villebichot and Villy-le-Moutier;
  • Department of Rhône: Avenas, Chasselay, Dardily, Dracé, Fleurieux-sur-l'Arbresle, Sain-Bel, Taponas and Villefranche-sur-Saône;
  • Department of Saône-et-Loire: Beaumont-sur-Grosne, Chalon-sur-Saône, Champforgeuil, La Chapelle-de-Bragny, La Charmée, Châtenoy-le-Royal, Chaudenay, Cluny, Cormatin, Demigny, Donzy-le-Pertuis, Farges-lès-Chalon, Flagy, Granges, Lalheue, La Loyère, Massilly, Messey-sur-Grosne, Saint-Ambreuil, Saint-Germain-lès-Buxy, Saint-Gervais-sur-Couches, Saint-Rémy, Saisy, Sancé, Taizé and Varennes-lès-Macon;
  • Department of Yonne: Aigremont, Annay-sur-Serein, Arcy-sur-Cure, Avallon, Bazarnes, Bessy-sur-Cure, Censy, Champlay, Champs-sur-Yonne, Chamvres, Châtel-Gérard, Chevannes, Coulangeron, Cruzy-le-Châtel, Escamps, Gy-l'Evêque, Héry, Island, Jouancy, Lichères-près-Aigremont, Lucy-sur-Cure, Mélisey, Merry-Sec, Molay, Montigny-la-Resle, Moulins-en-Tonnerois, Nitry, Noyers, Ouanne, Paroy-sur-Tholon, Pasilly, Pierre-Perthuis, Pontigny, Roffey, Rouvray, Sacy, Sainte-Pallaye, Sainte-Vertu, Sarry, Senan, Tissey, Vallan, Venouse, Vézannes, Villeneuve-Saint-Salves, Villiers-sur-Tholon, Vincelles and Yrouerre.

• (a) The name of the protected designation of origin may be followed by the term 'Clairet' for wines meeting the production conditions laid down for that term.
  • (b) The name of the protected designation of origin may be followed or supplemented by the terms 'primeur' or 'nouveau' for wines meeting the production conditions laid down for those terms. Wines bearing the terms 'primeur' or 'nouveau' must also state the vintage on the label bearing all mandatory information.
  • (c) Wines with the protected designation of origin may specify on their labels the name of a smaller geographical unit, provided that:
    • it is the name of a place in the land register;
    • it appears on the harvest declaration.

The place name as listed in the land register must be printed in letters no larger, either in height or in width, than half the size of the letters forming the name of the protected designation of origin.
